questions.question_text: What is your date of birth?
What is your employment status?
What is your annual income?
What is your primary source of income?

question_options.option_text: Pension Income, CPP/OAS or other government income

questions.question_text: What is the value of your liquid assets?
questions.description: Add up the money you have in savings and liquid investments.

questions.question_text: What is the value of your fixed personal assets?
questions.description: Add up the total value of real estate properties and other assets that can't be quickly and easily converted to cash.

questions.question_text: How much have you currently borrowed against your real estate properties?
questions.description: Add up the total value of real estate properties and other assets that can't be quickly and easily converted to cash.

questions.question_text: What is the current level of your consumer debt?
questions.description: Add up the balances on any lines of credit, car loans, student loans, credit cards and any other debt not used for real estate.

rules.description: Shows question if clients is U.S. Person
Shows question if clients is U.S. Person

questions.question_text: What types of debt do you have outstanding?

question_options.option_text: Mortgage and/or home equity line of credit (HELOC)
Money borrowed for investing or margin debt

questions.question_text: Suppose one year ago you invested $[[0.10 * {{NET_ASSETS}}]] in a portfolio. Today you checked its value and discover that it is now worth $[[0.087 * {{NET_ASSETS}}]]. How would you feel?

question_options.option_text: Panic – I’d want my advisor to sell, and invest the proceeds in cash
Nervous – I’d want my advisor to sell part of the portfolio and invest the proceeds in a less volatile investment
Calm – I’d sit tight, expecting the portfolio to recover
Positive – If I had any more money, I’d invest it in the portfolio

rules.description: Shows question if client has Power of Attorney

questions.question_text: Now suppose when you look at the portfolio again in 6 months, it is worth $[[0.074 * {{NET_ASSETS}}]]. How do you think you would feel?

question_options.option_text: Panic – I’d want my advisor to sell and keep the proceeds in cash
Nervous – I’d want my advisor to sell part of the portfolio and invest the proceeds in a less volatile investment
Calm – I’d sit tight, expecting the portfolio to recover
Positive – If I had any more money, I’d invest it in the portfolio

rules.description: Shows question if client has Power of Attorney

questions.question_text: Investments in which the initial investment is '100% safe' sometimes earn less than the inflation rate. This means that, while no money is lost, your money will buy less in the future. With respect to your goal(s), which of the following is most true?

question_options.option_text: My money should be '100% safe', even if it means my returns do not keep up with inflation.
It’s important that the value of my investments keep pace with inflation. I am willing to risk an occasional loss so that my investments can grow at about the same rate as inflation over time.
It’s important that my investments grow faster than inflation. I’m comfortable with some losses along the way.
It’s important that the value of my investments grow faster than inflation, but I would worry if in order to achieve this goal, there were too many ups and downs in the value of my investments.

rules.description: Shows question if client has Power of Attorney

questions.question_text: The biggest risk to my standard of living in the long term is:

You unexpectedly lose $[[0.06 * {{LIQUID_ASSETS}}]]. You are offered the chance to get it all back but there is a 30% chance that you could lose $[[0.17 * {{LIQUID_ASSETS}}]]. Would you take the chance?
Over the next few years, what do you think will happen to your income?

rules.description: Shows question if client has Power of Attorney
Shows question if client has Power of Attorney

questions.question_text: Based on your age, you have [[65 - {{AGE}}]] years until the traditional retirement age of 65. At 65, do you expect:

question_options.option_text: To be retired already and collecting a pension
To be retired already and living off of your savings

rules.description: Shows question if client has Power of Attorney

questions.question_text: How much would your standard of living be affected if the future income from your investment portfolio were to fall below your expectations?

question_options.option_text: It would have a significant impact. I cannot afford for this income to decrease and I will struggle financially
It would cause me to re-assess my standard of living and make some cut-backs
Not much as I have other ways to maintain my lifestyle

questions.question_text: Which of the following financial instruments have you invested in?
If given the choice of the following options, I would choose:

rules.description: Shows question if client has Power of Attorney

questions.question_text: If instead, I was given the choice of the following options, I would choose:
I plan to begin taking significant amounts of money from my investments in:
What is your most important investment goal?

question_options.option_text: To see modest growth in my money
To see significant growth in my money
To earn the highest return possible

questions.question_text: Which scenario would make you feel worse?

question_options.option_text: A stock went up 10% after I sold it
A stock went down 10% and I didn’t sell it

questions.question_text: How secure are your current sources of income?
Suppose a relative left you an inheritance of $[[0.33 * {{LIQUID_ASSETS}}]], stipulating in the will that you invest ALL the money in ONE of the following choices. Which one would you select?

question_options.option_text: A savings account or money market mutual fund
A mutual fund that owns both stocks and bonds
A handful of small mining and/or internet stocks

questions.question_text: How many months of current living expenses could you cover with your present savings and liquid short-term investments, before drawing on your investment portfolio?
Interest rates are currently low, significantly lower than they have been in the past. From here, interest rates are likely to:

question_options.option_text: Increase back to the long term average of 5.24%

questions.question_text: In the past three years, my outlook for the stock market has:
You and your advisor have invested in shares of a company that you expect will double in value in 2-3 years. The share price drops 30% soon after you buy. You:

question_options.option_text: Buy more and decrease your average price
Call your advisor to see what they could possibly have been thinking

questions.question_text: When I provide my money to an advisor:

question_options.option_text: I rarely look at my statements and expect them to let me know the results
Review each trade that the advisor recommends
Carefully track my entire portfolio daily and contact my advisor if I have questions
I look at my statements monthly to stay informed
I look at my statements only just before the regular review with them

questions.question_text: If I were to prioritize my goals, I would put them in the following order...
questions.description: Rank from 1 to 5 with 1 being your highest priority

questions.question_text: You unexpectedly receive $[[0.25 * {{LIQUID_ASSETS}}]], what would you do with it?

question_options.option_text: Pay off debt or my mortgage
Take a holiday or buy a car

rules.description: Shows question if client has Power of Attorney

questions.question_text: I would...

question_options.option_text: Deposit most of it in my bank account
Invest most of it in stocks
Invest most of it in a balanced portfolio of stocks and bonds
Invest most of it in a bond portfolio

rules.description: Shows question if client has Power of Attorney
Shows question if client has Power of Attorney

questions.question_text: Based on your age, you are expected to live for an additional [[84 - {{AGE}}]] years. Do you believe that your income, savings and assets will be sufficient to ensure your quality of life for that long?

question_options.option_text: If there isn’t a market meltdown

questions.question_text: How would you characterize your personality?

question_options.option_text: I'm a pessimist and always expect the worse
I'm anxious, and worry about most things
I'm cautious, but open to new ideas
I'm objective, and will live with my decision
I'm optimistic, things always work out in the end

questions.question_text: With my investments, what is most important is that:

question_options.option_text: The total value of my portfolio doesn’t go down
My portfolio generates enough cash for me to withdraw if I need it
I can watch my portfolio grow steadily over time

questions.question_text: Suppose that you are the only income earner in the family, and you have a good job guaranteed to give you your current family income every year for life. You are given the opportunity to take a new and equally good job, with a fifty-fifty chance it will increase your standard of living by 50%. However, the new job also has a fifty-fifty chance that it will cut your standard of living by 30%. Would you take the new job?

rules.description: Shows question if client has Power of Attorney

questions.question_text: Suppose the chances are fifty-fifty that it would increase your standard of living by 50% and fifty-fifty that it would cut it by 50%. Would you take the job?

rules.description: Shows question if client has Power of Attorney

questions.question_text: Suppose the chances are fifty-fifty that it would increase your standard of living by 50% and fifty-fifty that it would cut it by 20%. Would you take the job?
To keep track of my investments during the market meltdown in 2008-2009:

question_options.option_text: I looked at my investments every day
I only looked at my monthly statements
Put aside my statements because I didn’t want to scare myself
Didn't realise there was an issue until I saw my year-end report
I did not have any investments at the time

questions.question_text: Suppose you have $1,000 in a savings account with a generous 2% annual interest rate. After 5 years, how much do you think you would have in the account if you left the money to grow?
For your kids, you want:

question_options.option_text: To leave them whatever is left after you enjoy your retirement
To provide for their needs now (education, first house, etc.) even if it impacts your future standard of living
To let them know you are giving it away to charity

questions.question_text: How long would you be willing to wait for your portfolio to regain any lost value, given the fluctuations of any investment portfolio?
From September 2008 through November 2008, North American stock markets lost over 30%. If you owned an investment now that lost over 30% in 3 months, you would...

question_options.option_text: Sell all of the remaining investment to avoid further losses
Sell a portion of the remaining investment to protect some of your capital
Hold onto the investment and not sell any of the investment in the hopes of higher future returns
Buy more of the investment now that prices are lower

questions.question_text: Suppose you have a saving account with a 1% annual interest rate, and the inflation rate was 2% per year. After 1 year, how much would you be able to buy with the money in the account?
Relative to 5 years ago, I’m feeling ______ about the outlook for the financial markets / the economy in general?
Compared with others, how would you rate your willingness to take financial risks?
